column420: title:"How To Create a Social Network That Makes Money"
column422:
body:"

Creating a successful social network is no easy task. Making money from it is arguably even harder. Peter Ward knows this better than most. Ward is co-founder and chief executive officer (CEO) of WAYN (Where Are You Now?) a British-Polish startup and social network for travellers.

\

column1:
WAYN is a veteran in the social media world. It has seen the rise of networks such as Facebook and Snapchat as well as the fall of others such as Myspace and Friendster since its inception in 2002. In that time WAYN has been able to survive and carve out its own niche purpose and following of around 23 million members.

\
It has not been an easy task. The network had to operate on a shoestring budget for much of its development and a large part of its on-going growth. Initially WAYN raised around $15
column2: 000 in seed funding
column3: says Ward. Financing has become a bit easier to come by since then. In 2012 it underwent another round of funding
column4:
raising $5.5m \xe2\x80\x93 with a large contribution coming from Scottish Equity Partners.

\

column1: Ward and his co-founders made a big breakthrough in 2005 that led to WAYN\xe2\x80\x99s current success. At the time
column2: the network was struggling to attract new members in a cost-effective way. \xe2\x80\x9cWe were resorting to giving out fliers on the street

column1: <fbs-quotecard article-quote-card=\\"\\" ticker=\\"GOOGL\\" exchange=\\"NASDAQ\\" type=\\"organization\\" natural-id=\\"fred/company/1821\\" closing-price=\\"946.579\\" current-price=\\"950.489\\" link=\\"/companies/google/\\" name=\\"Google\\"> \

ad-words worked but were costing more per new member than we would be able to earn from them.\xe2\x80\x9d

\
At the time the site had fewer than 50
column2: 000 members. The founders of WAYN discovered that many users were joining but few would take the time to go through the process of manually adding their friends \xe2\x80\x93 resulting in a missed opportunity for membership growth and
column4:
a shorter period of activity as users that did not make new connections might drop out.

\

column1: \

A social network diagram (Photo credit: Wikipedia)

\

WAYN created a system where users could automatically send invites to friends in their email address book \xe2\x80\x93a now ubiquitous feature that was virtually non-existent at the time. This led to a massive increase in membership \xe2\x80\x93 over one million within six months and continued growth from there
column2:
says Ward.

\

column1: This massive increase got the ball rolling and helped to ensure WAYN\xe2\x80\x99s continued survival. The problem then became one of effectively commercialising the network and its user-base. \xe2\x80\x9cThe networks that succeed are the ones with a clear commercial mindset
column2:
\xe2\x80\x9d says Ward. \xe2\x80\x9cNew startups that try to be social and then make money typically don\xe2\x80\x99t survive beyond a point.\xe2\x80\x9d

\

column1: WAYN had an idea for commercial success. As users connected and discovered new places to visit
column2:
WAYN could capitalise through the provision of services such as bookings either directly on the site or through tie-in third-parties. But that doesn\xe2\x80\x99t mean it\xe2\x80\x99s been a straight road.

\

column1: \xe2\x80\x9cAt one point we had a Tinder-esque service allowing travellers to meet up
column2:
\xe2\x80\x9d says Ward. \xe2\x80\x9cIt kept the lights on and allowed us to continue to grow but it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t the nexus of what we wanted.\xe2\x80\x9d The network has subsequently redirected back to its core objective \xe2\x80\x93 helping people discover where they should go on holiday through social interaction and travel reviews.

\

column1: The next step is taking this data and codifying it to offer better options and a more tailored
column2: personalise experience to users. This includes collecting and mapping data on what activities are good in any particular destination

column1: \xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99re making the user experience more targeted and relevant \xe2\x80\x93and that means we get a higher return on every user experience
column2: \xe2\x80\x9d he says. \xe2\x80\x9cIf we can convert users to discover more or make a booking
column3:
it means we\xe2\x80\x99ve done a good job in bringing them what they want.\xe2\x80\x9d

\

column1: The number of social media sites continue to rise. There\'s no way of knowing what the next big thing is. But by ensuring a social media site has a commercial objective
column2: a niche area of interest and the determination to succeed on a small budget
column3:
a startup has a chance to succeed.

\

column1: \

Growth in Social Network Patent Applications (Photo credit: Wikipedia)

\

Ward is co-founder and chief executive officer (CEO) of WAYN (Where Are You Now?) a British-Polish startup and social network for travellers. WAYN is a veteran in [...]"

column55: description:"I am a London-based journalist covering international business and investment opportunities for entrepreneurs throughout the world. I believe entrepreneurship can transform the world economy and be the best tool for addressing issues in the developing world.  I look at interesting and unusual business models
column56: how society supports and interacts with entrepreneurs and the role technology plays in entrepreneurship and innovation. I also look at what red-tape
column57: rules and regulations budding entrepreneurs will face as they explore new markets. I currently also write for the international business and investment publication
column58: PathfinderBuzz.com and the market analysis publication
column59: ECigintelligence.com. I previously worked as a freelance journalist
column60: writing for publications such as International Business Times
column61: The Grocer and AGI Magazine. Prior to that I worked for the industry publication

column83: food and why we fight for a start). Header: Flickr

column2: personalise experience to users. This includes collecting and mapping data on what activities are good in any particular destination

column1: \xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99re making the user experience more targeted and relevant \xe2\x80\x93and that means we get a higher return on every user experience
column2: \xe2\x80\x9d he says. \xe2\x80\x9cIf we can convert users to discover more or make a booking
column3: it means we\xe2\x80\x99ve done a good job in bringing them what they want.\xe2\x80\x9d

column1: The number of social media sites continue to rise. There\'s no way of knowing what the next big thing is. But by ensuring a social media site has a commercial objective
column2: a niche area of interest and the determination to succeed on a small budget
column3: a startup has a chance to succeed.
